title: How is Nietzsche related to German Nationalism? - Quora

response.answer_text: He was and is one of the finest, highest products of the Spirit of the German Nation, if you want to put it in 19th Century terms. So, much as anything else might count, a Nationalist is bound to exalt him as the noblest part of his nation’s heritage. There’s no escaping that treatment, it’s like writing a book on the history of the English language and trying not to mention Shakespeare. This said, the man himself hated German Nationalism with a passion. He wasn’t an internationalist (although, as a cultured and curious European of his day, he took much of his intellectual identity from dealing with Archilochus, Horace, Dostoevskij and Maupassant), but he’d had a Nationalist phase, up to the Franco-Prussian war of 1870, when he served as a field nurse, which left him quite bummed for two big reasons: 1) Nationalism in his day seemed to kowtow to a staunchly bourgeois and comfortable lifestyle, as far as can be from his vitalistic approach to life and thought; and 2) his animalistic, vital ideal man, striving to become a beyond-man (“Overman”), is perhaps determined, in part, by the circumstances of his birth, but is not so much proud of them as much as his countrymen might be proud of their relation to him. So Nationalism was, in his understanding, a big distraction from striving to get to the Übermensch. Plus, he was immensely annoyed by Nationalist groups and especially those obscure Völkisch or antisemitic clubs and, above all, his sister and her proto-Nazi husband. He went as far, in trying to get those people off him (“They keep on sending me their damned newsletters!”) as to claim Polish heritage — probably on account of his surname’s outlandish spelling — even though he considered that Nation dirty and coarse. Thinking about it, I can’t really think of many modern Nations he didn’t disparage as such (British, Jews, etc.). Talking in terms of cultural/political movements, his ideas can only be appreciated by one precise segment of German Nationalists, the aristocratic, cultured Nationalists, who traditionally have tended to represent Rightwing Nationalism (eg. Jünger, von Salomon). There’s a few reasons for this, first and foremost the shared (“high”) culture and aristocratic mentality, but that’s a very rich subject and I’m not going to open that can of worms here. Leftwing Nationalists (eg. those pesky Nationalist Socialists) have historically tended to come from a much lower cultural background than Nietzsche (no shame in that, the man was a University professor before he’d graduated), so their support to his ideas is mostly a token or from hearsay. They quoted him because they thought he was a big, strong German, but couldn’t understand that he would’ve spat in their faces if they’d met. That’s where some superficial spectators later thought they saw some links between him and the Nazis.

The actual Nazi interest in Friedrich Nietzsche was not anti-Semitism. Although Nietzsche did write several phrases that could be (and were) taken the wrong way. he was never an anti-Semite, and some of his friends were Jewish. The actual Nazi interest in Friedrich Nietzsche was related to Nietzsche’s hatred of Democracy in all its forms. Nietzsche was consistent about this point, from his very first writings to his very final writings. Democracy is for Christians which is a “slave morality,” while truly strong people reject both. For Nietzsche, there were two kinds of people in this world — the strong minority and the weak majority. The strong were born to rule over the weak. That’s the “master morality.” That is how life should really have been, but the Christian movement took over (due to its “resentment” against the strong), and this led to Democracy, which for Nietzsche meant “rule by the weakling majority.” The actual Nazi interest in Friedrich Nietzsche was their interpretation that the Aryan race was the “strong minority” which was destined to rule the world, which was the “weak majority.” To do this, they had to first destroy Democracy and all its forms. They would start with France and England, and then move to Russia. Nazi soldiers carried the books of Nietzsche with them to battle.

The short answer is that he's not. The more nuanced answer is that in the last years of his life, he came to suffer very severe mental illness and his sister took over his estate. She and her husband could be considered something like proto-nazis. They released work under his name and edited it to make it seem like it would support hypernationalist ideals. Nietzsche himself was way too much an individualist to ever be much of a nationalist.
